awd_titl_txt: Fabrication of High Performance Metasurfaces by Nanoimprinting of Refractive Index
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant supports manufacturing research that advances knowledge pertaining to the fabrication of optical devices, an effort which promotes scientific progress in emerging technologies with the potential to advance national health, prosperity, and defense.  Specifically, this research advances key capabilities in cost-effective nanomanufacturing of components known as metasurfaces, which can be tailored to manipulate light with almost arbitrary wavefront shaping control.  This important technology holds relevance in areas such as biomedical imaging, optical communications, laser imaging detection and ranging, and optical management for laser trapping and solar energy applications.  Nearly all currently available manufacturing processes for producing metasurfaces rely on structuring optical materials through patterning followed by material etching or deposition. This general approach faces fundamental limitations which impact metasurface performance, manufacturing yield, and scalability. This project conducts fundamental research that investigates an innovative fabrication pathway wherein a material's optical properties are directly manipulated and patterned at high resolution without any deposition or etching. In addition to supporting the fabrication of existing metasurface architectures this approach uniquely enables new metasurface designs offering superior operating bandwidths and fabrication tolerances. This award supports training of skilled workers to enter into science, technology, engineering, and math careers, provides support for research experiences at the undergraduate level, offers opportunities to integrate research within the undergraduate classroom, encourages women and underrepresented minorities and supports local outreach activities which fosters interest in science for K-12 students.

The technical scope of this work includes: (a) developing a method for patterning refractive index on the surface of a chip with nanoscale resolution, (b) mapping the morphological tuning of porous nanomaterials to effective optical properties, (c) demonstrating the straight-forward fabrication of high performance metasurfaces with both binary and arbitrary refractive index profiles, and (d) offering a transformative new approach for non-resonant (broadband) phase control which overcomes interparticle spacing limitations and improves fabrication tolerance. This research focuses on a technique wherein porous substrates are locally imprinted and densified at high resolution by direct imprinting with three-dimensionally mastered stamps then planarized. With the aim of developing this nanomanufacturing approach to enable the cost effective fabrication of high performance metasurfaces, this research addresses key questions regarding process parameters, process variation and control, mechanical integrity, optical quality, and process limitations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:

This award supported the development of a novel and scalable nanomanufacturing approach "nanoimprinting refractive index" (NIRI) as well as the development of novel planar optical components including multifunctional metasurfaces, waveguides, and biosensors. Specifically, this research has introduced a new method for patterning refractive index on the surface of a chip with high resolution and high refractive index contrast (~1 RIU), based on a simple nanoimprinting process.  This technique is widely adaptable and can be applied to the realization of many types of optical structures.  Functional optical components including lenses and waveguides were successfully fabricated and tested using this technique for the first time. Addtionally, this research has advanced the capabilities of modern colorimetric sensors and biosensors.  Through the introduction of a novel sensing technique: "hyperchromatic structural color" which is based on the combination of a multi-chrome laser illuminant and a structural color filter/sensor this resarch demonstrated record level colorimetric sensitivities for label-free biosensing.  This opens the door to new research avenues which could unlock low-cost and high sensitivity diagnostics and other types of sensors which provide a large colorimetric response to small perturbations in input stimuli.

Broader Impacts:

Societal benefits of this research include pioneering a scalable route for low-cost flat-optic fabrication which circumvents hurdles of conventional fabrication routes, as well as pioneering new low-cost point-of-care biosensing platforms, and planar waveguide components. Advancements in these areas hold potential for realizing positive impacts on public health and well-being. Such technologies impact public health through their ability to provide medically relevant diagnostic information in a low-cost and rapid format, potentially without the need for expensive laboratory benchtop equipment.  Similarly, the development of a low-cost optical fabrication process may assist in the development of lower-cost consumer goods and new device form factors, e.g. in augmented reality displays.  Such technologies may contribute to the economy and foster improved productivity in the future workforce.

 

Products:

This award supported the research of three B.S. students from underrepresented groups, fostering their training in science and technology and enhancing their competitiveness in the job or graduate school market; 2 M.S. degrees; and one Ph.D. degree. An INTERN supplement supported one six month internship at Intel Corporation which led to a full time employment offer. Graduate students who participated in the project have since entered the STEM workforce in the U.S. This award supported in whole or in part seven peer-reviewed publications and >10 conference presentations.
